b.font:
If you are done the exam, click here to checkout. Only checkout once to remove your quiz access.
If you do not checkout you will receive a zero on the exam.

text.p: Implement a function that meets the specifications below.
text.pre: def binToInt(s): """ assumes: s is a str containing only 0's and 1's returns the int corresponding to the binary number represented by s. If s is empty, returns 0. """
text.p:
For example, the following code should print 10 twice.
print(binToInt('1010')) print(binToInt('01010'))
Paste your entire function, including the definition, in the box below. Do not leave any debugging print statements.

codeparam.answer_display: def binToInt(s): """ assumes: s is a str containing only 0's and 1's returns the int corresponding to the binary number represented by s. If s is empty, returns 0. """ res = 0 indx = 0 while indx < len(s): res += int(s[indx])*2**(len(s)-1-indx) indx += 1 return res

problem.p: Note: An L379 or L397 error: means that your code has an infinite loop for some test case. You will receive a zero for this problem if your code has an infinite loop.

Note on Score Shown: Your code will ultimately be run on our test cases. Getting "Correct"/green check during the exam does not mean you will get full points. The test cases here ensure you do not have a copy/paste error from your IDE.
